title: How did medieval politics differ from modern politics? - Quora

response.answer_text: Estates of the realm - Wikipedia I’d say the three biggest differences are: The church was a dominant political force and many monarchs were officially coronated by the pope. In modern times many nations have secular governmentsIn the modern west, republicanism is dominant whereas in medieval times monarchy was dominant.Meritocracy is common now but previously everything was based in birth into specific social classes.

One big difference is that in modern republics, political words and actions must aim at influencing a large portion of a very large electorate. Medieval politics had to concentrate on gaining the favor of the sovereign and those whom he most relied on, so that one could influence their actions.

There was no strong sense of nationality. Most people believed in the rights of hereditary rulers to rule. The various city-states had a narrow view of citizenship. Sometimes several grades of citizen with different rights. Oaths and inherited loyalties were considered binding.
Medieval European kingdoms were feudal. they had no concept of democracy as we know it.
